4-4 Consider the LP problem Minimize: Subject to:
a. Solve this problem using the simplex method. b. Draw the two-variable function space to verify your solution.

answer.para:
Problem 4-4 of gives one optimization function and four constraints. These equations, since they are linear, can be translated into a tableau and operated on by the simplex method to iteratively find the objective's minimum. The reader is expected to know or reference linear programming terminology, which can be found in chapter 4 of
or . is an introductory online textbook that covers linear programming and the application of the simplex method. I have put the objective functions are on the bottom rows of my tableaus.

The translation of the given equations into a tableau yields . This tableau is not in canonical form (LPSF), apparently because there are no basis variables. Two constraint equations with excess variables could be multiplied by negative one to form a basis set, but then the constraints would be negative, leaving the problem in non-canonical form agian. The way to resolve this situation is to augment the constraint equations with two positive numbers whose sum is another objective function and then subtract the constraints from the new objective, as shown in
and . Once the new objective is minimized to zero via the simplex method, the auxillary variables may be eliminated as shown in
and . Notice that no further optimization is necessary after this point because the coefficients of the variables not in the basis are positive.

The solution is verified by a contour plot of the function over its linearly constrained domain in . The red lines indicate constraints. The green point indicates the optimimum achieved by the simplex method. The green line indicates an entire edge of the domain that results in a minimum with the same value as the simplex method optimum. This optimum edge arises as a consequence of the edge and the function contours being parallel. Function contours and the minimum are labeled.

4-5 Consider the LP problem Minimize: Subject to:
a. Solve this problem using the simplex method. b. Draw the two-variable function space to verify your solution.

answer.para:
Problem 4-5 is the same as its predecessor, except that it has a different right hand value on one of its contraints that changes the domain of the optimization. Except for the inital part, the problem follows exactly the same solution steps. The problem, as given, is not in canonical form. This time, because one of the excess variables is negative and its corresponding constraint is negative, I can just multiply that equation by negative one. However, the equation set must still be augmented with artificial variables like problem 4-4 because another basis variable can't easily be selected. The entire process from initial equations to optimized solution is otherwise the same as problem 4-4. Solution steps are shown in
through .

The solution is verified by a contour plot, similar to the plot in problem 4-4 . Notice there is no optimum edge because neither of the two edges that touch the minimum are parallel with the objective contours.
